text: so this is the 22nd national poll that
the Harvard Institute of Politics has
done surveying attitudes among young
adult voters what did you find we found
that overall there's much less
enthusiasm about politics in general and
specifically about this campaign
compared to where we were four years ago
so President Obama swept and co-opted
into office in 2008 largely on the
support of an overwhelming but since
then we've seen some drifting happening
where our young adults today well Susan
we've seen drifting in two different
scenarios one is among the people who
are overall excited to participate in
the election and the number of people
will actually be turning out on Election
Day there's been significant drift there
where the number of Millennials folks
under the age of 30 will be
significantly less I predict then we'll
see compared to 2008 number one number
two he's seen some drifting where in
2008 he won among Millennials by a 66
and 32 margin against John McCain and
it's not quite there yet we still put
him in the mid-50s the drop-off in
enthusiasm is striking what do you think
is behind those numbers I think a couple
of things I think there's a segment of
the electorate who participate in 2008
because it was a thing to do it was
truly a historic moment in the history
of our country and there was some folks
who aren't necessarily engaged with
politics on a day to day basis who went
out and cast that vote to tell the
family and their kids and perhaps our
grandkids that they helped change the
course of America so there's some
drifting among that group and certainly
it's been a very difficult time over the
last couple of years in terms of the
economy and challenges that young people
have and they've been frankly extremely
disappointed in all of Washington losing
trust and faith in public institutions
which is going to created some
disaffection now those who are sticking
with mr. Obama say their expectations
have changed they're expecting oh this
is a generation that specially the the
younger Millennials is a generation that
came of age not from 9/11 and Katrina
but actually came of age during the
Great Recession
so they've much more pragmatic
today than they were I think a couple of
years ago and when we asked young people
which of two statements comes closest to
their own view almost two-thirds of
young people say the challenges that
Bhama had were so complex and difficult
it takes four years more than four years
to do the job now overall Hispanic
voters overwhelmingly support President
Obama compared with mr. Romney but among
Hispanic youth we're seeing something
that's quite different
what's going on with young adults well
it's a two-part question because the
first part they do those who vote do
support Obama overwhelmingly the problem
among young Hispanics is that they're
significantly less likely to vote than
their African American and in white
voters in fact in our most recent survey
less than 40 percent say they'll
definitely vote which is of concern
because three of the most important
swing states have a very high
concentration of aspects obviously
Colorado New Mexico in Florida one of
the things I think is so enlightening
about this poll is that it is part of a
continuum and you've been watching
trends since 2000 rather closely and you
can really say a lot about the direction
of youth attitudes in the country based
on your findings although today a lot of
the attitudes look like the attitudes
from 2000 in terms of disinterest and
politics and political structure young
Americans continue to care deeply about
their country they may not vote in the
numbers we like them to vote but they
are participating through civic
organizations to call commuter service
and volunteerism and those kinds of
things
